Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Trajectories of Risk and Resilience in the Health and Psychological Adjustment of College Students in Response to COVID-19

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The COVID-19 pandemic has produced major disruptions of physical and mental health and of economic stability. Previous research on pandemics and their impacts on society has rarely documented the consequences or risk/protective factors of acute mental health outcomes of young adults in the United States. This study will assess the self-identity, health, and psychological well-being of young adults during and after the pandemic. These young adults will be a critical part of the U.S. workforce in future decades, and the functioning of our society will depend on how they emerge from this pandemic. This study will also explore the extent to which income level and minority status influence the effects of the pandemic on health outcomes and will identify factors associated with high levels of risk and resilience. In turn, this will help create new integrated young adult mental health interventions to mitigate the challenges caused by COVID-19 and similar future disrupting events. <br/><br/>Using a prospective cohort design, this project will address three fundamental research challenges. First, it will determine trajectories of the mental/physical health status of diverse young adults based on their gender, income, and ethnicity/race in responses to the current pandemic. Second, it will identify risk and protective factors for specific mental disorders (e.g., depressive disorder, anxiety disorder, PTSD). Third, it will assess young adults’ pandemic experience and their efforts to overcome the challenges presented by COVID-19 by conducting qualitative in-depth interviews. Outcomes from this study will elaborate development theory in ways that can help design an integrated response to the pandemic that improves health and psychological outcomes among young adults.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The age of onset for lifetime mental health problems directly coincides with traditional college years in the US. Previous studies found that 75% of lifetime mental health problems will onset by age 24. Thus, it is vital to understand the status and trend of mental health problems among young adults during the COVID-19 pandemic.  

NSF funding has led our research team (PI. Hahm, Boston University, School of Social Work, and PI. Liu, Brigham and Women’s Hospital) to demonstrate that US young adults suffer from an unprecedented mental health crisis. We present five key findings regarding mental health issues among this population.   

First, we found that approximately 30-45% of young adults reported that they suffered from clinical depression, anxiety, and PTSD during the first 3 months of the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, high levels of loneliness, high levels of COVID-19 specific worry, and low distress tolerance were found to be risk factors that predict poor mental health outcomes. However, a high level of resilience and social support from their own family were associated with lower levels of mental health symptoms. Among college students, our study demonstrated that those who experienced mandated relocation reported a high level of worry, grief, loneliness, depression, anxiety, and PTSD compared to those students who did not experience mandated relocation.

Second, our study discovered that anti-Asian discrimination in the face of COVID-19 was more widespread than initial reports indicate: seven out of ten Asian American young adults reported that they or their family members experienced covert or overt COVID-19-related discrimination. Our team also demonstrated the significant correlations between COVID-19-related discrimination and elevated PTSD symptoms among Asian American young adults during the COVID-19 pandemic.

In addition, we wanted to find out if non-Asian American participants experienced vicarious anti-Asian discrimination. Analysis of open-ended questions related to the current social climate showed that not only did both Asian and non-Asian participants report witnessing or hearing reports of anti-Asian discrimination, but both groups described having negative affective reactions to anti-Asian discrimination.  

Third, we found that poor mental health was associated with poor physical health functioning among the young adults during the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, Black and Hispanic/Latinx participants were more likely to report poorer physical health functioning compared to White counterparts.  

Fourth, we also wanted to test if sexual and gender minority (SGM) young adults were experiencing a higher level of mental health problems compared to their heterosexual counterparts. Our study found that approximately 33% identified as sexual or gender minority in our survey. They had significantly higher levels of depression and PTSD symptoms as well as COVID-19-related worries and grief than non-SGM, even after controlling for important covariates.  

Fifth, we also compared the rates of mental health problems during Wave I to Wave II, using longitudinal data and analytic methods. Approximately 41% reported depression and 47% reported anxiety at Wave I; rates did not differ at Wave II. Individuals with greater financial concerns were 14% more likely to report high depressive symptoms; those with COVID-19 risk concerns and social climate concerns were 21% and 54% more likely, respectively, to score high on generalized anxiety. This study highlights the role of social climate and COVID-19 on anxiety, depression, and financial concerns among young adults.  

In conclusion, our study findings suggest that there is a strong need for mental health support and appropriate resources to mitigate the mental health crisis among US young adults. Future research is necessary to determine the long-term impacts of the pandemic on mental health, physical health, substance use, and quality of life among young adults in the US to call for action to provide a higher quality of mental health care for this population. This means the development of culturally and ethnically diverse mental health care, training and hiring more clinicians who are people of color in the university setting mental health services, and addressing COVID-19 specific distress in mental health treatment.
